prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 mosaic observations of IRAS 13134-6242
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 7 mosaic observations for the source IRAS 13134-6242, which include observations of 12CO(3-2), 13CO(3-2), CS(7-6), H13CN(4-3), and several transitions of CH3CN and CH3(13)CN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Band: The reason for choosing CO(3-2) in Band 7 as the main line to map the outflow in this source is two-fold: 2) We have single-dish maps of the CO(3-2) outflow for this source (see Figure 2), so we know it can de detected at this transition, and we can use the single-dish data to get an approximate size of the outflow and the expected line brightness. 2) Outflows from high-mass young stellar objects have higher excitation temperature than those of low-mass protostars and are typically brighter in higher excitation lines. Hence, we choose (3-2) over lower transitions. We do not use the (6-5) line, as it would have taken too many pointings to cover the desired region.
Angular Resolution: We choose a resolution of 0.8" in order to have linear resolution of about 2500 AU. We want to measure the outflow cavity opening angle, or at least put tight constrains on its size. These cavities are expected to be a few thousand AU in size. Studies of outflow entrainment (e.g., Arce & Goodman 2002) and outflow-core interaction (e.g., Arce & Sargent 2006) of nearby low and intermediate mass YSOs show that a resolution of about 1500 to 2500 AU is required to conduct a thorough study.
Mosaic Map + ACA: We aim to map the known extent of the CO(3-2) outflow (based on single-dish maps). To cover a 70" by 36" region (see Figure 2) we need a mosaic with 43 pointings. Given our proposed angular resolution our observations will require the C32-2 cycle 2 configuration. This configuration has a maximum recoverable scale of 7.2". This is not enough to recover the extended emission from the core (which is expected to be a few 0.1 pc, or 20" to 40"). We thus require ACA +TP data to recover all flux from the core and the low-velocity outflow near cloud velocities in order to obtain accurate mass estimates of both outflow and core. The ACA observations are also important for a complete modeling of the line profiles using radiative transfer, including the self-absorption spectra indicative of infall; missing flux could mimic self-absorption and we want to avoid that.
Spectral Set-up: We aim to observe lines that trace different density and kinematic regimes in the core and outflow (see Science Justification). A velocity resolution of ~0.1 to 0.2 km/s is required for most lines in order to resolve kinematic signatures in the core (e.g., rotation, infall, gradients due to outflow impact on dense gas, etc.). Sometimes outflow-core interactions produce subtle velocity gradients that may be missed with a lower velocity resolution. If needed, we will smooth the CO spectrum to a resolution of 0.5-1 km/s to study the low-density (low-intensity) very high-velocity outflow.
Sensitivity: We seek to detect the high-velocity wings of 12CO and 13CO(3-2), as well as the lines that trace the core. From single dish observation of the 12CO and 13CO(3-2) line with APEX (see Figure 3), we estimate the an rms of 0.3K, with a velocity resolution of 0.2 km/s is enough to detect the line core and high-velocity wings with a S/N > 5. For very high CO outflow velocities we can smooth to 1 km/s to obtain an rms of ~0.1 K in order to detect the very low-intensity high-velocity gas. ALMA Cycle 0 Band 7 observations from an unrelated project of another, similar, HMYSO (with 3e4 solar luminosities) show that the brightness temperature of the CH3CN(19-18) K=0,1,2 (which we propose to observe here) is about 30K. Hence, our sensitivity will be enough to detect this and other CH3CN and CH3(13)CN lines with a S/N > 5.
Time: The ALMA sensitivity calculator estimates that about 3.8 minutes of on-source integration time is needed to reach our desired sensitivity. This requires 1.5 min. per pointing for a total of 1.1 hrs of on-source time for the 12m array mosaic, or 2.7 hrs including calibration and overhead. An additional 10.9 hrs of ACA+TP time are required to cover the region.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 mosaic observations of IRAS 16351-4722
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 7 mosaic observations for the source IRAS 16351-4722, which include observations of 12CO(3-2), 13CO(3-2), CS(7-6), H13CN(4-3), and several transitions of CH3CN and CH3(13)CN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Band: The reason for choosing CO(3-2) in Band 7 as the main line to map the outflow in this source is two-fold: 2) We have single-dish maps of the CO(3-2) outflow for this source (see Figure 1), so we know it can de detected at this transition, and we can use the single-dish data to get an approximate size of the outflow and the expected line brightness. 2) Outflows from high-mass young stellar objects have higher excitation temperature than those of low-mass protostars and are typically brighter in higher excitation lines. Hence, we choose (3-2) over lower transitions. We do not use the (6-5) line, as it would have taken too many pointings to cover the desired region.
Angular Resolution: We choose a resolution of 0.8" in order to have linear resolution of about 2500 AU. We want to measure the outflow cavity opening angle, or at least put tight constrains on its size. These cavities are expected to be a few thousand AU in size. Studies of outflow entrainment (e.g., Arce & Goodman 2002) and outflow-core interaction (e.g., Arce & Sargent 2006) of nearby low and intermediate mass YSOs show that a resolution of about 1500 to 2500 AU is required to conduct a thorough study.
Mosaic Map + ACA: We aim to map the known extent of the CO(3-2) outflow (based on single-dish maps). To cover a 36" by 36" region (see Figure 1) we need a mosaic with 23 pointings. Given our proposed angular resolution our observations will require the C32-2 cycle 2 configuration. This configuration has a maximum recoverable scale of 7.2". This is not enough to recover the extended emission from the core (which is expected to be a few 0.1 pc, or 20" to 40"). We thus require ACA +TP data to recover all flux from the core and the low-velocity outflow near cloud velocities in order to obtain accurate mass estimates of both outflow and core. The ACA observations are also important for a complete modeling of the line profiles using radiative transfer, including the self-absorption spectra indicative of infall; missing flux could mimic self-absorption and we want to avoid that.
Spectral Set-up: We aim to observe lines that trace different density and kinematic regimes in the core and outflow (see Science Justification). A velocity resolution of ~0.1 to 0.2 km/s is required for most lines in order to resolve kinematic signatures in the core (e.g., rotation, infall, gradients due to outflow impact on dense gas, etc.). Sometimes outflow-core interactions produce subtle velocity gradients that may be missed with a lower velocity resolution. If needed, we will smooth the CO spectrum to a resolution of 0.5-1 km/s to study the low-density (low-intensity) very high-velocity outflow.
Sensitivity: We seek to detect the high-velocity wings of 12CO and 13CO(3-2), as well as the lines that trace the core. From single dish observation of the 12CO and 13CO(3-2) line with APEX (see Figure 3), we estimate the an rms of 0.3K, with a velocity resolution of 0.2 km/s is enough to detect the line core and high-velocity wings with a S/N > 5. For very high CO outflow velocities we can smooth to 1 km/s to obtain an rms of ~0.1 K in order to detect the very low-intensity high-velocity gas. ALMA Cycle 0 Band 7 observations from an unrelated project of another, similar, HMYSO (with 3e4 solar luminosities) show that the brightness temperature of the CH3CN(19-18) K=0,1,2 (which we propose to observe here) is about 30K. Hence, our sensitivity will be enough to detect this and other CH3CN and CH3(13)CN lines with a S/N > 5.
Time: The ALMA sensitivity calculator estimates that about 3.8 minutes of on-source integration time is needed to reach our desired sensitivity. This requires 1.4 minutes per pointing for a total of 31 min. of on-source time for the 12m array mosaic, or 1.4 hrs including calibration and overhead. An additional 5.4 hrs of ACA+TP time are required to cover the region.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 mosaic observations of IRAS 16533-4009
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 7 mosaic observations for the source IRAS 16351-4722, which include observations of 12CO(3-2), 13CO(3-2), CS(7-6), H13CN(4-3), and several transitions of CH3CN and CH3(13)CN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Band: The reason for choosing CO(3-2) in Band 7 as the main line to map the outflow in this source is two-fold: 2) We have single-dish maps of the CO(3-2) outflow for this source (see Figure 2), so we know it can de detected at this transition, and we can use the single-dish data to get an approximate size of the outflow and the expected line brightness. 2) Outflows from high-mass young stellar objects have higher excitation temperature than those of low-mass protostars and are typically brighter in higher excitation lines. Hence, we choose (3-2) over lower transitions. We do not use the (6-5) line, as it would have taken too many pointings to cover the desired region.

Studies of outflow entrainment (e.g., Arce & Goodman 2002) and outflow-core interaction (e.g., Arce & Sargent 2006) of nearby low and intermediate mass YSOs show that a resolution of about 1500 to 2500 AU is required to conduct a thorough study.
Mosaic Map + ACA: We aim to map the known extent of the CO(3-2) outflow (based on single-dish maps). To cover a 50" by 50" region (see Figure X) we need a mosaic with 39 pointings. Given our proposed angular resolution our observations will require the C32-2 cycle 2 configuration. This configuration has a maximum recoverable scale of 7.2". This is not enough to recover the extended emission from the core (which is expected to be a few 0.1 pc, or 20" to 40"). We thus require ACA +TP data to recover all flux from the core and the low-velocity outflow near cloud velocities in order to obtain accurate mass estimates of both outflow and core. The ACA observations are also important for a complete modeling of the line profiles using radiative transfer, including the self-absorption spectra indicative of infall; missing flux could mimic self-absorption and we want to avoid that.
Spectral Set-up: We aim to observe lines that trace different density and kinematic regimes in the core and outflow (see Science Justification). A velocity resolution of ~0.1 to 0.2 km/s is required for most lines in order to resolve kinematic signatures in the core (e.g., rotation, infall, gradients due to outflow impact on dense gas, etc.). Sometimes outflow-core interactions produce subtle velocity gradients that may be missed with a lower velocity resolution. Sensitivity: We seek to detect the high-velocity wings of 12CO and 13CO(3-2), as well as the lines that trace the core. ALMA Cycle 0 Band 7 observations from an unrelated project of another, similar, HMYSO (with 3e4 solar luminosities) show that the brightness temperature of the CH3CN(19-18) K=0,1,2 (which we propose to observe here) is about 30K. Hence, our sensitivity will be enough to detect this and other CH3CN and CH3(13)CN lines with a S/N > 5.
Time: The ALMA sensitivity calculator estimates that about 3.8 minutes of on-source integration time is needed to reach our desired sensitivity. This requires 1.6 min per pointing for a total of 1 hr of on-source time for the 12m array mosaic, or 2.7 hrs including calibration and overhead. An additional 10.7 hrs of ACA+TP time are required to cover the region.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to conduct a small survey of high-mass young stellar objects in order to study the outflows they power, the cores where they from and the impact outflows have on their surroundings. Studies of outflow-core interactions have been frequently conducted for low-mass protostars, but there is a lack of similar studies for high-mass protostars. This pilot study of three typical, high-mass star forming regions aims to alleviate this. We will use Band 7 to observe lines that trace various density and kinematic regimes in the outflows and cores. With our data we aim to investigate the entrainment process in these massive outflows by conducting a detailed study of their morphology and velocity structure and comparing our results with entrainment models. We will also study the density distribution and kinematics of the parent cores (i.e., infall, rotation, turbulence, gradients due to outflow). This will allow us to investigate the role outflows play in the generation of turbulence, and in heating and dispersing the core gas. Our study aims to increase our knowledge of how stellar feedback impacts the mass-assembling process during the early stages of massive star formation.
